title: The Framing of Decisions and the Psychology of Choice

studies.study_name: The Asian Disease Problem (Lives Saved vs. Lives Lost)

findings.main_hypothesis: Choices involving gains are often risk averse and choices involving losses are often risk taking; framing the same objective outcomes as gains or losses will reverse preference.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Preference for certain gain (Program A) > risky gain (Program B) AND Preference for risky loss (Program D) > certain loss (Program C)
statistical_tests.reported_statistics: Problem 1: Program A (72%), Program B (28%); Problem 2: Program C (22%), Program D (78%)

original_data_points.description: Percentage of participants choosing each program in gain-framed (Problem 1) and loss-framed (Problem 2) scenarios.

findings.main_hypothesis: When facing concurrent decisions, individuals frame choices narrowly, leading to the selection of a combined portfolio that is stochastically dominated by an alternative portfolio.

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: The majority will choose the combination (A & D) in Problem 3, even though the combination (B & C) is shown to be superior in Problem 4.
statistical_tests.reported_statistics: Problem 3: 73% chose A & D, 3% chose B & C. Problem 4: 0% chose A & D, 100% chose B & C.

original_data_points.description: Choice percentages for individual options and combined patterns in concurrent vs. integrated frames.

studies.study_name: Framing of Contingencies (Certainty and Pseudocertainty Effects)

findings.main_hypothesis: A reduction in the probability of an outcome has more impact when the outcome was initially certain than when it was merely probable (Pseudocertainty effect).

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Preference for the 'certain' option will be high in the single-stage (Prob 5) and two-stage (Prob 6) versions, but will shift to the higher-EV risky option in the probabilistic version (Prob 7).

original_data_points.description: Preference for a smaller-sure-gain vs. larger-risky-gain across different probability frames.

studies.study_name: Psychological Accounting (Theater Ticket vs. Cash Loss)

findings.main_hypothesis: The willingness to purchase a ticket depends on whether a prior loss is posted to the same psychological account (the ticket) or a different account (general cash).

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Willingness to pay for a ticket after losing $10 cash > Willingness to pay after losing a $10 ticket.
statistical_tests.reported_statistics: Problem 8 (Lost Cash): 88% Yes; Problem 9 (Lost Ticket): 46% Yes.

original_data_points.description: Percentage of respondents willing to pay $10 for a theater ticket after a $10 loss.

studies.study_name: Psychological Accounting (Saving on Jacket vs. Calculator)

findings.main_hypothesis: People evaluate price savings in a minimal account (relative to the item price) rather than an inclusive account (total purchase price).

statistical_tests.statistical_hypothesis: Willingness to travel for a $5 saving is higher when the saving is on a $15 item than on a $125 item.
statistical_tests.reported_statistics: Version 1 ($15 calculator): 68% willing; Version 2 ($125 calculator): 29% willing.

original_data_points.description: Willingness to drive 20 minutes to save $5 on a calculator depending on the calculator's price.

overall_original_results.description: A comprehensive repository of choice percentages for all decision problems presented in the paper.
